narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project titled 'NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants' expects to generate demographic, clinical, and MRI-based imaging data. This includes structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS data, along with derived imaging measures/features and supporting documentation such as data dictionaries, protocols, and README files. The dataset will comprise participant-level clinical/demographic tables for 220 participants (110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls) and multi-modal MRI imaging data. The total volume of the data will depend on the imaging protocols used and the derivatives retained, with the imaging data expected to be the largest component.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected data, including demographic and clinical data (in tabular form) and MRI-based imaging data, will be preserved and shared. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and further research in the field by providing a comprehensive dataset that can be used by other researchers. This approach aligns with the principles of open science and maximizes the potential benefits of the research conducted.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible:
- Data dictionaries that describe the variables and their formats in the demographic and clinical datasets.
- Study protocols outlining how the MRI imaging data were collected.
- README files providing an overview of the dataset structure, content, and any specific instructions for use.
- Information on the standardized scan protocols used for acquiring MRI data.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools and software will be needed to access or manipulate the shared scientific data, particularly for analyzing the MRI imaging data. These include but are not limited to:
- MRI analysis software such as FSL (FMRIB Software Library) or AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages).
- Statistical software like R or Python libraries (e.g., pandas, NumPy, and scikit-learn) for handling and analyzing the demographic and clinical data.
These tools can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. Specifically:
- The MRI data will adhere to the BIDS (Brain Imaging Data Structure) standard for organization and formatting.
- Demographic and clinical data will follow standardized formats such as those recommended by the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) for data sharing, including the use of standardized vocabularies and ontologies where applicable.
These standards ensure that the data can be easily understood, accessed, and combined with other datasets.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository that specializes in storing and sharing data related to mental health research. The NDA provides a secure, reliable, and accessible platform for data sharing, facilitating collaboration among researchers.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the assignment of a persistent unique identifier (e.g., DOI) upon deposition into the NDA. Additionally, metadata will be fully indexed and searchable within the NDA's database, allowing users to locate specific datasets based on various criteria such as study description, participant demographics, or data types.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data are expected to remain accessible for a minimum of 10 years following the initial release, in accordance with NIH guidelines and the policies of the NDA.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While the project aims to maximize data sharing, factors such as privacy and confidentiality protections for human research participants may limit certain aspects of data access. Specifically, all shared data will be de-identified to protect participant privacy. However, access to the data may be controlled through a request and approval process managed by the NDA to ensure that data use agreements are in place to safeguard sensitive information.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Yes, access to the scientific data will be controlled. The NDA will manage access through a system where users must register and agree to terms of use before being granted access to the datasets. This ensures that data are used responsibly and in compliance with ethical standards.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer:
To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, several measures will be implemented:
- All data shared through the NDA will be de-identified to remove direct identifiers.
- Participants will provide broad consent for data sharing as part of the study's informed consent process.
- Certificates of Confidentiality will be obtained to further protect against disclosure of sensitive information.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI) in conjunction with the institution's research administration office. Regular oversight will occur at least bi-annually, or as needed based on milestones such as data collection completion or publication of results. Responsibilities include ensuring that all project staff understand and adhere to the Plan, coordinating data deposition into the NDA, monitoring access requests and ensuring compliance with data use agreements, and reviewing feedback from users to improve data sharing practices. This oversight ensures that the project meets its obligations regarding transparent and responsible data sharing.
